Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Controlled Syntheses of pi-Conjugated Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Anne J. McNeil of the University of Michigan Ann Arbor is supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Division of Chemistry to study Ni-catalyzed chain growth polymerization for the synthesis of pi-conjugated polymers and copolymers. The aims of the proposed research include (a) obtaining insight into the mechanism of transition-metal-catalyzed chain-growth polymerizations, (b) synthesizing, characterizing, and evaluating new Ni0-arene -complexes as intermediates and initiators, (c) developing new synthetic methods to provide access to a new class of functional organic materials with novel properties and applications, and (d) elucidating the fundamental reactivity preferences when multiple monomers are used.

The proposed research promises to advance our understanding of the metal-catalyzed polymerization of conjugated polymers, with the potential of increasing the diversity of conjugated materials available for applications in technological devices, including thin-film solar cells and light-emitting diodes. Graduate and undergraduate students will be trained in multidisciplinary research involving organic, inorganic, and polymer chemistry. Students and other faculty members will be engaged in a comprehensive overhaul of chemical entries in Wikipedia.

Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor

POR.DRECONTENT:
While most organic polymers are colorless insulators, a subset of polymers can absorb/emit light as well as conduct charge. These polymers are known as conjugated polymers, and are comprised of repeating units containing alternating double/single or triple/single bonds. Conjugated polymers have the potential to revolutionize the electronics industry by providing light-weight, low-cost alternatives to silicon in applications such as solar cells, light-emitting diodes, and transistors.

 

For decades, conjugated polymers were prepared using step-growth polycondensations, wherein monomers were randomly coupled in solution. These approaches are ultimately limited because the polymer molecular weight (or mass) and the sequence of repeat units are difficult to control. This synthetic landscape changed dramatically in 2004, when a chain-growth method for synthesizing conjugated polymers was first reported. In a chain-growth method, monomers are added to an activated polymer chain end, which enables the researcher to control the polymer length (by specifying the monomer/initiator ratio) and sequence (by controlling the feed composition). These initial reports sparked a flurry of activity in the field, and more than 150 papers using this new method have been published since 2004. From these studies, several limitations have been documented: for example, there is a limited number of monomers which undergo this chain-growth polymerization and they are all largely electron-rich. In addition, copolymerizations between pairs of these monomers largely failed. The central goal of this NSF grant was therefore to develop new catalysts with a broader substrate scope using detailed mechanistic studies and identify the key intermediate that controls chain-growth behavior.

 

The most significant intellectual merits of our work completed under this grant include: (i) providing evidence for each intermediate in the catalytic cycle, (ii) demonstrating that certain ancillary ligands and metals improve the chain-growth polymerization by stabilizing a key intermediate, and (iii) selectively accelerating precatalyst initiation with appropriately tuned reactive ligands. In addition, we have made some progress on expanding the scope of monomers by (i) elucidating the mechanistic bottleneck that is occurs when electron-deficient monomers are used, and (ii) developing a model system to identify new chain-growth catalysts. Given the significance and widespread use of metal-catalyzed reactions, these results have also made an impact on ongoing research in the synthetic organic, organometallic and polymer chemistry communities.

 

The most significant broader impacts of our work completed under this grant include (a) the highly interdisciplinary training of four graduate students, two post-doctoral scholars, and more than a dozen undergraduate students in organic synthesis, inorganic synthesis, polymer synthesis and characterization, organometallic reaction mechanisms, kinetics, and spectroscopy, and (b) improving the science content on Wikipedia, as >150 students made substantial edits to existing (and new) science-focused pages through participating in my course project, which has enhanced the quality and quantity of scientific information available to the general public while providing students training in advanced scientific concepts, collaborative learning, and effective communication.

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2015
Modified by: Anne J Mcneil
